85793dd1775fbc0c0562493f069bcaa2 (16:24): a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3: I also have a question about WebIDL
85793dd1775fbc0c0562493f069bcaa2 (16:24): Let's say I want to unambiguously express that the foo attribute extends the definition of the Bar interface, how?
85793dd1775fbc0c0562493f069bcaa2 (16:25): The real case here is for to place an instance of Widget on the Window interface, as "widget"
85793dd1775fbc0c0562493f069bcaa2 (16:25): without claiming to redefine all of Window
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (16:25): the way existing specs do this is to define an additional interface, call it WindowWidget
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (16:25): which has that attribute
85793dd1775fbc0c0562493f069bcaa2 (16:26): yeah, that's what I was hoping to avoid :)
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (16:26): and then you know the rest i guess :)
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (16:26): yeah so webidl doesn't have a shorthand to express that
85793dd1775fbc0c0562493f069bcaa2 (16:26): not planned either?
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (16:26): well i'm not convinced
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (16:26): it seems kinda weird to be able to augment an interface
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (16:27): for strongly typed languages, anyway
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (16:27): i suppose there could be an extended attribute something like this:
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (16:27): [ImplementedOn=Window] interface WindowWidget { ... }
c5e3539121c4944f2bbe097b425ee774 (16:27): Yeah, I was thinking about this some more... the interfaces have to be abstracted away from the objects that implement them
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (16:27): which states that all Windows also implement WindowWidget

c5e3539121c4944f2bbe097b425ee774 (16:36): 85793dd1775fbc0c0562493f069bcaa2, so to avoid introducing a new NS, I need to change the name of the <update> element, either in the Packaging Spec or in the Updates spec.
85793dd1775fbc0c0562493f069bcaa2 (16:37): c5e3539121c4944f2bbe097b425ee774: your ultimate goal here is to?
85793dd1775fbc0c0562493f069bcaa2 (16:37): use the exact same semantics for the widget update document as for the configuration document?
c5e3539121c4944f2bbe097b425ee774 (16:38): I think it's bad language design to have two elements in the same namespace that have different semantics
85793dd1775fbc0c0562493f069bcaa2 (16:38): updatelocation, updateurl
c5e3539121c4944f2bbe097b425ee774 (16:38): but the same name
85793dd1775fbc0c0562493f069bcaa2 (16:38): I agree on that
c5e3539121c4944f2bbe097b425ee774 (16:38): <updatelink uri="http://blabla.com/update.php"> ?
85793dd1775fbc0c0562493f069bcaa2 (16:39): <updates url="..." maxfrequency="..." />

c5e3539121c4944f2bbe097b425ee774 (16:42): so, have <updates uri=""/> in the Config Doc, and <update> ... </update> in the Updates spec.
85793dd1775fbc0c0562493f069bcaa2 (16:42): a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3: main thing we want to express is that a compliant implementation SHOULD/MUST provide WindowWidget on Window

85793dd1775fbc0c0562493f069bcaa2 (16:43): I bet people are going to be confused no matter what you do, though

85793dd1775fbc0c0562493f069bcaa2 (16:57): yeah, but that implies either using multiple namespaces in the update document, or defining all elements that you want to repeat to have the exact same semantics as the packaging spec
